As a senior member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, these issues are of great importance to me and I look forward to hearing more about the concerns of those working in the transportation sector in my district

Following this, I will be taking a tour of the Sierra Energy facility and learning more about the work they do to promote clean energy in our community. I will then be moving to Marysville to meeting with my Transportation Advisory Board.

I am looking forward to a productive day in our district, where I will be spending time with constituents and meeting with community leaders.

Climate change presents a myriad of readiness challenges both at home and abroad. It is not only a future threat but is impacting resiliency of our installations and operations today. The Department must act now to address these challenges.
Not only are these climate-related events impacting installation readiness, but they are also creating more frequent requests for military support for disaster relief and humanitarian assistance.
"...They will likely lead to food and water shortages, pandemic, disease, disputes over refugees and resources, and destruction by natural disasters in regions across the globe.”

“Rising global temperatures, changing precipitation patterns, climbing sea levels, and more extreme weather events will intensify the challenges of global instability, hunger, poverty, and conflict...
To ensure it can perform its national defense mandate, the Department of Defense must plan for a variety of exigencies. In the 2014 Climate Change Adaptation Roadmap, the Department noted that...

Unfortunately, the report did not meet the congressional reporting
requirement to describe future focused mitigations necessary to ensure mission resiliency.

The required report was delivered to Congress in January 2019 and indicated that two thirds of the 79 installations reviewed are vulnerable to flooding, more than half are vulnerable to drought, and about half are vulnerable to wildfires.

It's essential that our bases and facilities recover quickly from extreme weather events and energy disruptions that impact mission capabilities. The FY18 National Defense Authorization Act required the Department of Defense to report on the Effects of Climate Change.
In many cases, through contract vehicles such as energy savings performance contracts, these energy saving and resiliency enhancing improvements can be made at no up-front cost to the Department.

One way to enhance readiness is to consume less. In FY 2017, the DOD consumed over 85 million barrels of fuel to power ships, aircraft, combat vehicles, and contingency bases at a cost of nearly $8.2 billion.
and the Department is uniquely situated to enhance its readiness and resiliency through effective energy policy and programs.

The U.S. military is one of the largest employers in the world. It is also one of its largest consumers of energy. The DOD owns millions of acres of global real property, including over 550,000 facilities valued over a trillion dollars...

Melting polar ice in Arctic regions has already opened new sea routes and competition for resources, yet it appears that DOD has not developed a systematic strategy for ensuring U.S. national interests in the Arctic.

California wildfires led to the evacuation of family housing at Camp Pendleton, Naval Air Station Point Mugu, and the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center. Our coastal installations are already experiencing significant flooding due to sea-level rise.

Is the US military ready for Climate Change? Recent events indicate considerable doubt. Just this last year Hurricanes Florence and Michael caused billions of dollars in damage to Camp Lejeune and leveled much of Tyndall Air Force Base.

Here's my opening statement as I kick off the Readiness Subcommittee's hearing on the effects climate change will have on the U.S. military

 https://armedservices.house.gov/_cache/files/9/e/9edb8a1c-5f51-4bb5-aba3-1ff9aa14b7b8/64AF705A74C1A11FB98988F9EE48DC6C.opening-statement---rdy-garamendi-3-13-19.pdf …

UPDATE: This hearing will now start at or around 2:15 ET. You can stream the hearing below

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lQarAvMb6rk … https://twitter.com/RepGaramendi/status/1105850578075377664 …

Today I am hosting a hearing on climate change in the Readiness Subcommittee: “Ensuring Resiliency of Military Installations in Response to Climate Changes.” I hope you will join me at 2pm ET/11am PT on C-SPAN as we discuss the military’s role in mitigating climate change.
Dreamers, TPS, and DED recipients strengthen our nation and I am proud to support this crucial legislation.
After the Trump Administration’s decision to rescind the DACA program in 2017, these groups have lived in fear of deportation and separation from their families. This is simply unacceptable.

I, along with my Democratic colleagues, am committed to ensuring that Dreamers and TPS and DED holders are protected and have a clear pathway to citizenship. In California and across the nation, Dreamers and TPS and DED holders contribute to our communities and economy.

THREAD:  https://www.vox.com/2019/3/12/18261574/dream-act-daca-tps-democrats-bill …

Today I co-sponsored H.R. 6, the Dream and Promise Act of 2019 to protect our nation’s Dreamers, as well as Temporary Protected Status (TPS) and Deferred Enforced Departure (DED) holders.

I won't allow this President's draconian budget request become law. Instead, I will fight to repair our roads, protect our environment, and expand opportunities for local farmers to ensure our government works #ForThePeople again.
Page 93: The budget requests a $2.8 billion or 31-percent decrease from the @EPA. Removing harmful pollutants and toxins from our air and water supply simply isn't a priority for this President.

Page 77: The budget requests a $5.9 billion or 22-percent decrease in the Department of Transportation's budget. That's less money to repair our roads, bridges, and other crucial projects in and around our community.

Page 57: The budget requests a $2 billion or 14-percent decrease from the Department of the Interior (including 2019 changes in mandatory programs). That could impact the Berryessa Snow Mountain in our district.

Page 15: The 2020 budget requests a $3.6 billion or 15-percent cut to @USDA (including changes in mandatory programs and receipts). That would take money directly from our large agriculture community in the 3rd District.

THREAD: The President's budget request is a heartless attack on programs that are crucial to my district, and a continuation of the White House's relentless attacks on California. Here's an overview of some of the terrible proposals in the President's budget request:
